Home.title: PCU Documentation
Home.description: A powerful CLI tool for managing pnpm workspace catalog dependencies
Home.heroTitle: Manage your pnpm catalogs with ease
Home.heroDescription: PCU helps you check, update, and analyze dependencies in your pnpm workspace catalogs efficiently.
Home.gettingStartedDesc: PCU is a dependency management tool designed specifically for pnpm workspaces. It helps you check for outdated dependencies, update versions in batch, and optimize your catalog configuration.

Quickstart.title: Quick Start
Quickstart.description: This guide will help you quickly install and configure PCU to start managing your pnpm catalog dependencies.
Quickstart.installDesc: PCU can be installed globally via npm, yarn, or pnpm. We recommend using pnpm for consistency.
Quickstart.configDesc: In your pnpm workspace root directory, ensure you have proper catalog configuration.
Quickstart.firstRunDesc: Run PCU to check the status of dependencies in your workspace.
Quickstart.nextStepsDesc: Now that you have PCU installed and performed your first check. Here are some useful next steps:

QuickstartPage.title: Quick Start
QuickstartPage.description: This guide will help you quickly install and configure PCU to start managing your pnpm catalog dependencies.
QuickstartPage.intro: This guide will help you quickly install and configure PCU to start managing your pnpm catalog dependencies. We'll cover how to install the tool, configure your workspace, and perform your first dependency check.
QuickstartPage.noteText: Before you start using PCU, make sure your project uses pnpm as the package manager and has workspaces configured. You can find the workspace configuration in the pnpm-workspace.yaml file at the root of your project.
QuickstartPage.chooseInstallDesc: Before your first check, you need to choose how to install PCU. In addition to traditional npm global installation, PCU also supports installation via pnpm, yarn, and temporary execution via npx. The following examples show how to install PCU:
QuickstartPage.firstCheckDesc: After choosing an installation method, you can perform your first dependency check in your pnpm workspace. The following examples show how to run PCU to check for outdated dependencies, displaying the first 10 results by default:
QuickstartPage.nextStepsDesc: Great! You now have PCU installed and have performed your first dependency check. Here are some useful links to help you explore more PCU features:
QuickstartPage.getCatalogLink: Get catalog configuration from pnpm workspace
